text:
I suspect that is meant to be tongue-in-cheek, but FWIW, because they’re so fast to train, we actually use them in situations where there’s streaming data coming in real-time, to train on-line(-ish) models (which we use along side gradient algorithms that were trained using 100's of hours of GPUs).

There may be better methods available, but what we have works pretty well!

(That said, I generally agree with the points made about gradient algorithms.)

elements.text:

There may be better methods available, but what we have works pretty well!

text: I also think that for some kinds of graph classification tasks, svms still seem to do best, although neural network methods often perform better, for example the result for NCI1 here: <https://paperswithcode.com/task/graph-classification>

elements.text: I also think that for some kinds of graph classification tasks, svms still seem to do best, although neural network methods often perform better, for example the result for NCI1 here:

text: Thanks simon and Kevin. Yes I was being a bit hyperbolic, but I thought that SVMs have largely fallen out of favor save for some niche use cases
